document.docTitle: Tengella kalebi Candia-Ramírez & Valdez-Mondragón, 2014, new species
document.masterDocTitle: A new troglobitic species of the spider genus Te ng e l l a Dahl (Araneae, Tengellidae) from Chiapas, Mexico

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new troglobitic species of the spider genus Te ng e l l a Dahl (Araneae, Tengellidae) from Chiapas, Mexico

figureCitation.captionText-0: FIGURES 1 – 4. Tengella kalebi new species. Male holotype. 1, Carapace, dorsal view. 2, Habitus, dorsal view, showing the long palps. 3, Habitus, ventral view. 4, Prosoma, antero-dorsal view, showing eyes poorly developed. Scales: 1 mm.
figureCitation.captionText-1: FIGURES 5 – 8. Tengella kalebi new species. Male holotype. 5, Left palp, ventral view. 6, Same, retrolateral view. 7, Same, prolateral view. 8, Same, dorsal view. Scales: 1 mm.
figureCitation.captionText-2: FIGURES 9 – 12. Tengella kalebi new species. Male holotype. 9, Left palp, ventral view. 10, Same, showing details of the conductor, embolus and median apophysis. 11, Same, showing details of conductor and embolus. 12, Same, ventral-retrolateral view. Scales: 100 µm (Fig. 11), 200 µm (Fig. 10), 500 µm (Figs 9, 12).
figureCitation.captionText-3: FIGURES 13 – 20. Tengella kalebi new species. Female paratype from Río Hondo Cave: 13, Spinnerets, ventral view (arrow indicates the colulus). 14, Detail of the spinnerets (arrow indicates the colulus). Female paratype from Río Hondo Cave: 15, 18, Epigynum, ventral and dorsal views respectively. Female paratypes from Sumidero del Higo: 16, 17, Epigyna, ventral views. 19, 20, Epigyna, dorsal views. Scales: 0.1 mm (Figs 15 – 20), 0.5 mm (Figs 13, 14).
figureCitation.captionText-4: FIGURES 21 – 27. Tengella kalebi new species. 21, Male holotype, ventral view of right chelicera (arrow indicates 4 retromarginal teeth). 22, Female paratype from Río Hondo, ventral view of right chelicera (arrow indicates 3 retromarginal teeth). 23, Male holotype, claws of left tarsus III. 24 – 27, Male holotype, left leg I. 24, Detail of the paired dorsal spines on tibia. 25, Detail of dorsal spines on metatarsus. 26, Detail of the ventral spine on tibia. 27, Detail of the claws (arrow indicates the unpaired third claw). Scales: 100 µm (Fig. 27), 300 µm (Fig. 24), 400 µm (Fig. 26), 500 µm (Fig. 25), 0.5 mm (Figs 21 – 23).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type data.
MEXICO : Chiapas:
1 male
holotype (CNAN-T0817) [
16 June 2011
; A. Valdez, O. Francke, C. Santibáñez, J. Cruz, R. Monjaraz, G. Contreras, K. Zárate cols.] from Río Hondo Cave (lat 17.11454 °, lon - 92.86448 °; 1642 m ), Municipio Jitotol. Paratypes :
1 female
(CNAN-T0818), same data as holotype .
1 female
(CNAN-T0819) [
3 April 2011
; K. Zárate col.] from Sumidero del Higo (lat 16.969608 °, lon - 93.120492 °; 230 m ), Ejido de Benito Juárez, Municipio San Fernando.
1 female
(CNAN-T0820) [
16 January 2011
; K. Zárate col.], same locality as previous record.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–4.
Tengella kalebi
new species .
Male holotype. 1, Carapace, dorsal view. 2, Habitus, dorsal view, showing the long palps. 3, Habitus, ventral view. 4, Prosoma, antero-dorsal view, showing eyes poorly developed. Scales: 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. This species is dedicated to the speleologist and friend Kaleb Zárate Gálvez of the Speleological Group Jaguar A. C. from Chiapas; for his contribution to the knowledge of the arachnids of caves from Chiapas, Mexico , and his participation in the collecting of the type series.

Diagnosis.
Tengella kalebi
resembles
T. perfuga
and
T. radiata
, these three species are distinguished from
T. albolineata
and
T. thaleri
by having tegulum less voluminous; by having embolus and median apophysis longer; and principally by having epigynum with a wide median septum (
Figs 15–17
), although the female of
T. albolineata
is unknown, the epigynum of
T. thaleri
is composed by a small and conical septum (
Platnick, 2009 ; fig. 12
).
Tengella kalebi
is distinguished from
T. perfuga
and
T. radiata
by having the male palp with cymbium shorter and oval ( Figs 5, 8 ); by the embolus long and less curved ( Figs 5 , 9 ;
Leister et al ., 2013
, figs 5 B, 6 B, 6 E); by the median apophysis wider and longer (
Figs 5 –7
,
9, 10
), with a thin longitudinal furrow ( Figs 10, 12 ), whereas in
T. perfuga
and
T. radiata
the median apophysis is thinner and shorter (
Leister et al ., 2013
; figs 5 B, 6 B, 6 E), even in
T. perfuga
it has several small denticles (
Leister et al ., 2013
; figs 5 B, 5 C); by the RTA simple, shorter, slightly curved in retrolateral view, reddish distally, with two tips, one larger and conspicuous and the other shorter and inconspicuous (
Fig. 6
), whereas in
T. perfuga
the RTA is wide and flat apically in ventral view (
Leister et al ., 2013
; figs 6 B, 6 G), in
T. radiata
the RTA is wide and flat, step-shaped in retrolateral view (
Leister et al ., 2013
; figs 6 F, 6 J); and by the median septum of the epigynum pear-shape in ventral view, having the lateral lobes more separated than in
T. perfuga
and
T. radiata
(
Figs 15–17
;
Leister et al ., 2013
; figs 7 A, 7 C), in
T. perfuga
the median septum is wider, almost circular (
Leister et al ., 2013
; figs 5 D, 7 A), in
T. radiata
the median septum is almost square-shaped (
Leister et al ., 2013
; figs 7 C).

Legs: All segments pale yellow, dorsally darker. Leg spination (only surfaces bearing spines listed) (details of leg spination shown in
Figures 24–27
): femora: I d 1 - 0-1 , p 1 - 1 - 1 , r 1 - 1 - 1 ; II d 1 - 0-1 , p 1 - 1 - 1 , r 1 - 1 - 1 ; III d 1 - 0-1 , p 2 - 1 - 1 , r 1 - 1 - 1 ; IV d 1 - 0-1 , p 1 - 1 - 1 , r 0-1 - 1 ; tibiae: I d 1 -0-0, p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; II p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-1 ; III d 1 - 0-1 , p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; IV d 1 - 0-1 , p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; metatarsi: I p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; II p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; III d0- 0-1 , p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; IV d 2 - 0-2 , p 0-1 -0,
v 2 - 1
- 1 . Tarsi with three claws, lacking claw tufts; paired claws with numerous teeth basally, distal teeth larger ( Figs 23, 27 ); unpaired claw long, lacking denticles (arrow,
Fig. 27
); tarsi without thick ventral scopulae; all trochanters with shallow notches.

Measurements: Total length (prosoma + opisthosoma excluding chelicerae and spinnerets) 6.45 , carapace: 3.50 long, 2.80 wide, width at level of the palp 1.55 . Opisthosoma: 3.00 long. Leg lengths: I: coxa 1.22 / trochanter 0.28 / femur 5.10 / patella 1.70 / tibia 5.40 / metatarsus 5.25 / tarsus 2.80 / total 21.75 ; II: 1.24 / 0.36 / 5.30 / 1.70 / 5.80 / 5.40 / 2.80 / 22.60 /; III: 1.32 / 0.28 / 5.40 / 1.60 / 5.60 / 5.70 / 2.80 / 22.70 ; IV: 1.42 / 0.28 / 5.80 / 1.60 / 5.90 / 7.70 / 3.60 / 26.30 . Leg formula: 4321 .

Female paratype .
( CNAN T0818). Coloration and morphology as in the male, except for the legs, which are shorter and stouter. Leg spination: (only surfaces bearing spines listed): femora: I d 1 - 0-1 , p0- 0-1 , r 1 - 1 - 1 ; II d 1 - 1 - 1 , p 1 - 1 - 1 , r 1 - 1 - 1 ; III d 1 - 0-1 , p 1 - 1 - 1 , r 1 - 0-1 ; IV d 1 - 0-1 , p 0-1 -0, r 0-1 - 1 ; tibiae: p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; II p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0- 1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; III d 1 - 0-1 , p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; IV d 1 - 0-1 , p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; metatarsi: I p 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; II p 0-1 - 0, r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 , III d0- 0-1 , p 1 - 0-1 , r 1 - 0-1 ,
v 2
- 0-2 ; IV p0- 0-1 , p 1 - 1 -0, r 1 - 1 - 1 ,
v 2 - 1
- 1 .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 5–8.
Tengella kalebi
new species .
Male holotype. 5, Left palp, ventral view. 6, Same, retrolateral view. 7, Same, prolateral view. 8, Same, dorsal view. Scales: 1 mm.

FIGURES 9–12.
Tengella kalebi
new species .
Male holotype. 9, Left palp, ventral view. 10, Same, showing details of the conductor, embolus and median apophysis. 11, Same, showing details of conductor and embolus. 12, Same, ventral-retrolateral view. Scales: 100 µm (Fig. 11), 200 µm (Fig. 10), 500 µm (Figs 9, 12).

FIGURES 13–20.
Tengella kalebi
new species .
Female paratype from Río Hondo Cave: 13, Spinnerets, ventral view (arrow indicates the colulus). 14, Detail of the spinnerets (arrow indicates the colulus). Female paratype from Río Hondo Cave: 15, 18, Epigynum, ventral and dorsal views respectively. Female paratypes from Sumidero del Higo: 16, 17, Epigyna, ventral views. 19, 20, Epigyna, dorsal views. Scales: 0.1 mm (Figs 15–20), 0.5 mm (Figs 13, 14).

subSubSection.paragraph: Measurements : Total length 7.75 , carapace: 3.55 long, 2.70 wide, width at level of palp 1.70 . Opisthosoma: 4.20 long. Leg lengths: I: coxa 1.30 / trochanter 0.26 / femur 4.05 / patella 1.60 / tibia 3.85 / metatarsus 3.37 / tarsus 1.85 / total 16.28 ; II: 1.27 / 0.32 / 4.15 / 1.56 / 3.90 / 3.60 / 2.00/ 16.80 ; III: 1.26 / 0.27 / 4.20 / 1.48 / 3.73 / 4.10 / 2.06 / 17.10 ; IV: 1.32 / 0.30 / 4.65 / 1.48 / 4.40 / 5.80 / 2.60 / 20.55 . Leg formula 4321 .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 21–27.
Tengella kalebi
new species .
21, Male holotype, ventral view of right chelicera (arrow indicates 4 retromarginal teeth). 22, Female paratype from Río Hondo, ventral view of right chelicera (arrow indicates 3 retromarginal teeth). 23, Male holotype, claws of left tarsus III. 24–27, Male holotype, left leg I. 24, Detail of the paired dorsal spines on tibia. 25, Detail of dorsal spines on metatarsus. 26, Detail of the ventral spine on tibia. 27, Detail of the claws (arrow indicates the unpaired third claw). Scales: 100 µm (Fig. 27), 300 µm (Fig. 24), 400 µm (Fig. 26), 500 µm (Fig. 25), 0.5 mm (Figs 21–23).

subSubSection.paragraph: Natural history. The specimens from Rio Hondo Cave were collected approximately 60 m inside the cave, which is located in a karst zone with a disturbed, semi-deciduous forest of medium height. They were found walking on the walls of the cave. The humidity inside the cave was high, around 90 % because a small subterranean river runs near the place where the specimens were collected.
